NH3 is the main product of nitrogen reduction and is not only an indispensable fertilizer component but also a promising clean energy carrier. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) can reduce N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions and is one of the most promising technologies to replace the traditional Haber–Bosch process. The careful choice and design of electrocatalysts are both key to achieving an efficient electrocatalytic reaction. In this study, using density functional theory calculations, the catalytic performance of a series of 3d transition metal (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) single-atom catalysts supported on C3N (TM@C3N) was systematically investigated. The best NRR performance was achieved for the Fe-C@C3N catalyst, and the reaction follows the enzymatic mechanism. Crucially, at a limiting potential of –0.49 V, the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction was effectively inhibited. Furthermore, the electronic properties of the reaction intermediates and Fe-C@C3N were analyzed to reveal the reasons for its high activity. The results of this study will help us understand the catalytic performance of TM-atom-doped C3N and aid the design of more active C3N-based NRR catalysts. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction Electrocatalysts DFT calculations Dope C3N surface Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is an important raw material for the production of fertilizer, medicines, and other products and, thus, plays an important role in human agriculture and society. However, the traditional industrial method for producing NH3 (the Haber–Bosch reaction) consumes a large amount of non-renewable energy resources. This will accelerate the emission of greenhouse gasses that are causing global heating, glacial melting, and other problems that serious threaten human society. Therefore, it is crucial to develop sustainable, economical, and environmentally friendly methods for NH3 synthesis to solve the global energy shortage while not contributing to the greenhouse effect. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) using water as a hydrogen source can be powered by renewable energy and carried out under ambient conditions. As a result, the NRR represents a promising route for green, sustainable, and cost-effective NH3 production. Compared to the Haber–Bosch process, the electrocatalytic NRR has lower energy input and simplified reaction steps and is more environmentally friendly [1–12]. However, the process still requires effective catalysts to break the strong NN bond. Therefore, new designs for efficient electrocatalysts for N2 fixation are urgently required. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have taken a leading position in the search for novel electrocatalysts [13–17]. The reduction of catalyst nanoparticles to a single atom can maximize catalyst utilization, and the distribution of single atoms on the support provides uniform active sites with high activity for the catalytic reaction. Nevertheless, the activity of SACs is highly influenced by the support [18–22]. Therefore, to design NRR electrocatalysts with high catalytic performance, it is urgent to screen the suitable supports. Good supports not only have a large specific surface area to disperse the isolated atoms but also a strong interaction with the SACs, thus preventing aggregation. Two-dimensional materials have been widely applied as supports for the electrocatalytic NRR because of their large surface areas, excellent electrical conductivities, high chemical stabilities, and adjustable electronic structures, as well as their useful morphological characteristics. Commonly used two-dimensional material supports include graphene [23, 24], graphyne (GY) [25–28], graphdiyne (GDY) [29, 30], graphite-like carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [31], polyaniline (C3N) [32], and molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) [33]. These surfaces are regarded as good supports for SACs because of their ability to enhance catalytic performance. For example, our research group has reported the catalytic performance of 3d and 4d TM single atoms supported on defective graphene (MVG and DVG) [23] and GY [25] as NRR catalysts. The highly active V@MVG and Mn@GY catalysts, which have free energy barriers for the NRR of 0.63 and 0.36 eV, were identified using density functional theory (DFT) calculations for catalyst activity and selectivity screening. Furthermore, by including the effects of S defect and stress, the catalytic activity of MoS2 as an NRR electrocatalyst was also investigated [33]. The results revealed that the S vacancy is the active site, and the application of tensile stress can enhance the catalytic activity and significantly inhibit the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Hou et. al. investigated potential electrocatalysts for the NRR with TM single atoms anchored on g-t-C3N4. After a six-step screening process, Fe@g-t-C3N4 and Os@g-t-C3N4 were identified as SACs having good structural stability and high selectivity and activity [31]. Moreover, analysis of their thermodynamic and kinetic stability revealed their potential for real-world synthesis. Wang et. al. reported the catalytic performance of N-doped GDY for the electrochemical NRR, and electronic property analysis indicated that N-doping greatly promoted N2 adsorption and activation. In addition, the graphitic-C vacancies efficiently reduced N2 at a low limiting potential of –0.41 V in the Mars–van Krevelen (MvK) pathway [29]. There are many available two-dimensional supports, and C3N, a novel monolayer graphene-based nanomaterial, is particularly promising. C3N can be synthesized by the direct pyrolysis of hexaaminobenzene trihydrochloride single crystals [34] or by the polymerization of 2,3-diaminophenazine [35]. Because of its hexagonal honeycomb graphene-like structure, the mechanical properties and stability of C3N are even better those of graphene. Therefore, C3N has been widely studied and has shown outstanding performance in several research fields, including electrocatalysis [32, 36, 37], CO2 storage [38], and Na-, K- [39], and Li-ion batteries [40]. Chen et. al. used first principles calculations to investigate and screen the potential of TM single atoms anchored on defective C3N monolayers (TM-VCC) as candidate catalysts for N2 fixation. Their results showed that the Mn-VCC catalyst significantly inhibited the HER and exhibited excellent NRR activity, having the favorable limiting potential of −0.75 V through the distal pathway [32]. Zeng et. al. also chose monolayer C3N as an ideal theoretical model and designed Be-doped and Cr-doped C3N catalysts. The results exhibited rather low theoretical overpotentials of these catalysts with 0.476 and 0.216 eV, respectively, for the alkaline HER. He et. al. studied B-doped C3N monolayers in an acidic environment for the oxygen reduction reaction [37]. In addition to high catalytic activity, high selectivity is also essential for electrocatalyst design. Because the cleavage of the NN bond requires a large reduction potential, and the H atom has a large affinity for metals, the HER occurs easily, resulting in a decrease in the efficiency and selectivity of NH3 production. Therefore, it is necessary to suppress the HER by improving catalyst selectivity. Crucially, DFT calculations can be used to explain the reaction mechanism [41–43], thus allowing rational design and the development of new materials having properties that exceed those of current commercial catalysts. In this work, we systematically investigated the NRR performance of a series of 3d TM (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) single atom doped C3N as candidate electrocatalysts using DFT calculations. The results showed that Fe-C@C3N exhibited excellent activity with a low limiting potential of −0.49 V. Furthermore, the activity of the competitive HER was effectively suppressed, suggesting its promising selectivity for the NRR. 2 Computational methods All spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP). The interactions between the nuclei and valence electrons were described using the projected augmented wave (PAW) method. The exchange correlation effects were described using Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional for the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [44–47]. To describe the van der Waals interactions, the empirical DFT-D3 method was used [48]. The plane-wave cutoff energy was set to 400 eV, the energy convergence precision was 10−5 eV, and the atomic relaxation convergence accuracy was less than 0.01 eV/Å per atom in force. For structural optimization and electronic property calculations, the k-points grids in the Brillouin zone were set to 3 × 3 × 1 and 7 × 7 × 1, respectively. The atoms in all structural optimizations were completely relaxed. The computational model for C3N was a 3 × 3 supercell containing 54 C atoms and 18 N atoms, and a 15 Å vacuum layer in the z-axis direction was used to avoid the interactions between adjacent periodic repeating units (Fig. 1 (a)). To demonstrate the kinetic stability of the catalyst, molecular dynamics simulations were performed in the NVT canonical ensemble. The thermodynamic stability of the TM-atom-doped C3N (TM@C3N) catalysts can be determined by calculating the formation energy (E f), as given by Eq. (1). (1) E f = E TM @ C 3 N + E C / N − E C 3 N − E TM Here, ETM@ C3N is the total energy of the TM-atom-dopd C3N surface, EC 3N is the energy of the pristine C3N surface, EC/N is the energy of atomic C and N in graphene and N2 molecule, and ETM is the energy of a TM single atom in metal bulk, respectively. Many nitrogen-containing intermediates are involved in the NRR electrocatalytic process. The adsorption strength of the intermediates on the active sites of the catalyst surface largely determines the catalytic effect. The adsorption strength can be expressed by the adsorption energy (E ads). A more negative E ads value indicates that the intermediates are adsorbed on the catalyst surface more strongly and the adsorption structure is more stable. These values can be calculated using Eq. (2). (2) E ads = E TM @ C 3 N − adso rbate − E TM @ C 3 N − E adso rbate Here, ETM@C3N-adsorbate, ETM@C3N , and Eadsorbate represent the total energy of the intermediates adsorbed on TM@C3N, the pure TM@C3N, and the energy of the intermediates, respectively. To evaluate the NRR catalytic performance of various systems, the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model was adopted to calculate the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of the reaction intermediates [49–51]. The relationship between free energy and electrode potential can be obtained using this theoretical model. Using the CHE model, the trend in the ΔG of each intermediate at a given potential during the electrocatalytic reaction can be obtained. Then the potential-determining step (PDS) of the reaction can be determined, which can be used to screen for the best catalytic materials. The ΔG of each reaction step in the NRR can be calculated using Eq. (3). (3) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G p H Here, ΔE is the total energy obtained from the DFT calculation, ΔE ZPE is the zero-point energy correction, T is the temperature (T = 298.15 K), and ΔS is the entropy change. ΔG U = –neU, where n is the number of transferred electrons and U is the electrode potential. In addition, ΔG pH = k B T × ln10 × pH, which is the ΔG value corrected for the H + concentration, and k B is the Boltzmann constant. In this study, chemical reactions under strongly acidic conditions were considered, so the pH was set to zero. Furthermore, the reaction H + + e− → 1/2H2 can reach equilibrium on a reversible hydrogen electrode without an applied voltage. Therefore, the total energy of one H ++ e− pair was equal to half the ΔG value of H2. The limiting potential (U L) is defined as U L = –ΔG max/e, in which ΔG max is the ΔG value of the PDS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of TM@C3N The primitive unit cell of C3N used in this study consisted of six C and two N atoms, and the optimized lattice parameter was 4.92 Å, which is consistent with the value reported previously [40, 52, 53]. A TM atom replaces one C or N atom in C3N to form two doped structures: TM-C@C3N and TM-N@C3N, as shown in Fig. 1(b) and 1(c), respectively. The interaction between the TM single atom and the support is very important for evaluating the stability and regulating the electronic properties to obtain high reactivity and selectivity. Therefore, the stability of TM-C@C3N and TM-N@C3N by calculating their formation energies (E f) were first determined. As shown in Table 1 , the E f values of all doped systems are negative, which indicates that the formation of TM-atom-doped C3N is favorable thermodynamically. Crucially, the TM-C@C3N and TM-N@C3N catalysts have high thermodynamic stability, suggesting that their synthesis might be experimentally favorable. 3.2 Screening TM@C3N as NRR electrocatalysts The adsorption and activation of N2 is a prerequisite for the entire NRR process to proceed smoothly. Therefore, the N2 adsorption on the different TM@C3N surfaces was first studied. The adsorption of N2 usually occurs in two configurations: in one, one of the N atoms at the end of N2 is connected to the TM atom active site; this is end-on adsorption. In the other, both N atoms are connected to the TM atom; this is side-on adsorption. The results are shown in Fig. 2 (a); compared to the side-on configuration, the end-on configuration of N2 is favored for TM@C3N. In particular, N2 was not adsorbed on Co@C3N in the side-on configuration. According to the Sabatier principle [54], the ideal NRR catalyst should have a moderately strong interaction with N2. This is because if the interaction between the catalyst and N2 is too weak, N2 cannot be fully activated, which will lead to a high activation barrier for the surface reaction. In contrast, if the interaction is too strong, NH3 desorption is disfavored, resulting in catalyst deactivation. The lavender colored region in Fig. 2(a) is the most favorable adsorption interval, having E ads ranging from –1.0 to –0.6 eV. Next, the NRR catalytic activities of the electrocatalysts were evaluated based on the ∆G value of the PDS. A smaller ∆G value indicates that the limiting potential and overpotential are lower. Thus, the energy input is also lower and the catalytic activity is higher. According to previous reports [25, 26, 55, 56], *N2H formation and *NH3 desorption are the key steps in the NRR, and the first (*N2→*N2H) and last (*NH2→*NH3) hydrogenation reactions are usually the PDS in the entire NRR. Therefore, to save computational resources, the ∆G values for *N2H formation were first calculated for screening, and the results are shown in Fig. 2(b). Among all candidate TM@C3N catalysts, only N2 adsorbed Fe-C@C3N in the side-on configuration, and this catalyst had a ∆G value of less than 0.6 eV. To determine the catalytic activities of the TM@C3N catalysts, we compared the N–N bond lengths (d N–N) and Bader charges of N2 adsorbed on the different TM@C3N surfaces. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), N2 adsorption in a side-on configuration was more conducive to weakening the N–N bond, and the d N–N values are larger, reaching more than 1.17 Å. In contrast, for N2 adsorption in the end-on configuration, the d N–N is only approximately 1.15 Å. In addition, we calculated the charge transfer between N2 and TM@C3N because a greater degree of charge transfer can activate N2 more efficiently, thus ensuring the subsequent hydrogenation step. Our calculations revealed that there was more charge transfer between N2 and TM@C3N, which resulted in an elongated N–N bond, thus activating N2 (Fig. 3(a)). Further, as shown in Fig. S1, the degree of stretching (d N–N) is positively correlated with the electron-withdrawing ability of N2, with an excellent linear correlation coefficient of R2 = 0.96 (end-on) and R2 = 0.87 (side-on), respectively. Thus, the adsorption of N2 in the side-on configuration is more conducive to the subsequent NRR steps. At the NRR reduction potential, the HER is the main competitive reaction [57, 58]. Therefore, an ideal NRR catalyst not only requires high NRR activity but must also be able to inhibit the HER effectively. The competition between HER and NRR can usually be evaluated in two ways: one is to calculate the adsorption free energy for atomic hydrogen (ΔG(*H)) and the other is to compare between E ads(*H) and E ads (*N2). Firstly, the absolute value of ΔG(*H) can used as a standard to judge the HER activity, as ΔG(*H) approaches zero, the catalytic activity for the HER increases. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the absolute values of ΔG(*H) for the TM-N@C3N catalysts are small: 0.17, 0.19, and 0.20 eV for Fe-N@C3N, Mn-N@C3N, and Cr-N@C3N, respectively. This suggests that high HER activity on these surfaces could hinder NRR progress. In contrast, the absolute value of ΔG(*H) for TM-C@C3N is relatively large, so the NRR is more likely to occur over these catalysts than the HER. In addition, the competition between HER and NRR is also evaluated by the comparison between E ads(*N2) and E ads(*H). For this, the following relationship was used: ΔE = E ads(*N2) – E ads(*H). The adsorption of N2 is more favorable for ΔE < 0, which is benefit for the NRR process, while HER is more favorable for ΔE > 0. As shown in Fig. 4(b), except for Co-N@C3N, the E ads (*H) values are all negative (< –0.4 eV), indicating that H can be adsorbed stably on TM@C3N. Further calculation of the ΔE values revealed that all TM@C3N surfaces except Mn-N@C3N have high NRR selectivity. Based on the above analysis, Fe-C@C3N has a moderate strength of N2 adsorption, low energy barrier for the first hydrogenation step, and good NRR selectivity. Therefore, in the subsequent calculations, the entire NRR process was simulated using the Fe-C@C3N model. 3.3 NRR mechanism on Fe-C@C3N Based on the above screening, N2 adsorbed on Fe-C@C3N in the side-on configuration is most conducive to the subsequent NRR, and the reaction process should follow the enzymatic and consecutive pathways (Fig. S2). From Fig. 6(a) and S3, the PDS of both pathways is the first hydrogenation step (*N–*N → *N–*NH). It's worth noting that the enzymatic pathway is the more common pathway, therefore, the free energy and origin of the catalytic activity of Fe-C@C3N is studied by taking the enzymatic pathway as the representative. Next, the ΔG values of the entire enzymatic pathway were analyzed in detail. As shown in Figs. 5 and 6(a), the first hydrogenation step to generate *N–*NH requires an external energy supply of 0.49 eV. In the second hydrogenation step, the H + + e− pairs attack the other N atom connected to the Fe atom (*N–*NH → *NH–*NH), and this step has a ΔG value of 0.12 eV. Subsequently, the H + + e− pairs continue to attack the two N atoms alternately in processes having ΔG values of –0.66 and –0.88 eV, respectively. During the above hydrogenation process, the N–N bond is gradually weakened by the attack by H + + e− pairs, and the corresponding d N–N are 1.17, 1.26, 1.38, and 1.43 Å for *N–*N, *N–*NH, *NH–*NH, and *NH–*NH2, respectively. The N–N bond breaks completely after generating *NH2–*NH2. The distal N atom is then hydrogenated to release one molecule of NH3 and produce *NH2, releasing an energy of 0.62 eV. In the final hydrogenation step, *NH2 is hydrogenated to *NH3 with a ΔG value of 0.31 eV. Thus, the first hydrogenation (*N–*N → *N–*NH) step is the PDS, and the corresponding ΔG barrier is 0.49 eV. 3.4 Origin of the catalytic activity of Fe@C3N Further, the adsorption energies, magnetic moments, and Fe–N bond lengths of various intermediates (*N x H y (x = 1, 2; y = 0 to 4)) adsorbed on the Fe-C@C3N catalyst were calculated, as shown in Fig. 6 (b). The changes in E ads show that *N–*NH, *NH–*NH, *NH–*NH2, *NH2–*NH2, and *NH2 interact strongly with Fe-C@C3N, and their E ads values are all below –2.5 eV. As the hydrogenation process progressed, the E ads values decreased gradually, and the corresponding d Fe–N also decreased. Notably, after *NH–*NH2 adsorption, one of the Fe–N bond was significantly elongated, which should promote the complete breakage of the N–N bond in the *NH2–*NH2 structure. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 6(a), the ΔG values of these hydrogenation steps are also negative, indicating that these processes are exothermic reactions. In comparison, the adsorption of *N2 and *NH3 is obviously weaker, and the corresponding Fe–N bonds are longer. Therefore, the *N2H formation and *NH3 desorption reactions are endothermic and require additional energy input, which is also consistent with the previously calculated ΔG values. The electronic configuration of Fe is 3d64s2, and there are four unpaired electrons in the d orbital, which can generate the electron spin magnetic moment. Moreover, the distance between adjacent Fe atoms and the radius of the unfilled inner electron shell is relatively large, so Fe has strong magnetic properties. Magnetic materials play a pivotal role in production, life, national defense science and technology, and have also been widely used in new technologies of information, energy, biology and space. Therefore, we studied the changes in the magnetic moment. As shown in Fig. 6(b), there was an odd and even oscillation in the magnetic moment during the *N x H y adsorption process. In particular, after *N2 and *NH3 adsorption, the magnetic moment value is zero. To reveal the catalytic activity of Fe-C@C3N, the Bader charges were calculated, and the charge transfer between *N x H y species and Fe-C@C3N was analyzed. The Fe-C@C3N catalyst model with *N x H y can be divided into three moieties (Fig. 7 (a)): the C3N support (moiety 1), Fe atom with two neighboring C atoms and one N atom (moiety 2), and *N x H y species (moiety 3). As shown in Fig. 7(b), moiety 2 acts is the active part and is responsible for charge transfer between moiety 1 and moiety 3. Considering the direction and degree of charge transfer, moiety 1 is the main electron donor, except for during NH3 adsorption, and the change in the amount of charge is relatively stable. Further, the adsorption of N2 causes the charge lost by moiety 1 to be transferred to N2 and moiety 2. In contrast, *N–*NH and *NH–*NH obtain electrons from moiety 2 and moiety 3 simultaneously, although moiety 3 provides more electrons. As the hydrogenation reaction proceeds, the ability of the *N x H y species to withdraw electrons is weakened, whereas their ability to lose electrons is enhanced. Thus a large number of electrons are transferred to moiety 2. Notably, moiety 2 gradually changes from an electron donor to an electron acceptor, and the charge accumulation further activates the N–N bond, with *NH2–*NH2 having the largest charge transfer (0.96 e). The N–N bond is completely dissociated at this point. Next, charge density difference maps were plotted to reveal the origin of the interaction between *N x H y and Fe-C@C3N. As shown in Fig. 8 , there is bidirectional charge transfer between *N x H y and Fe-C@C3N. The empty orbital of the Fe atom accepts σ electrons from *N x H y and contributes electrons to the antibonding orbital of *N x H y . Significant charge accumulation and depletion occur simultaneously between the anchored Fe atom and *N x H y , and the N–N bond can be fully activated by an "acceptance–donation" process. In terms of the degree of charge transfer, there is an obvious bidirectional charge transfer between *NH2–*NH2 and Fe-C@C3N, which is also consistent with the calculated amounts of charge transfer. Furthermore, the binding strength of between N–N bond can be measured by the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) obtained. The COHP curves of the N–N bond for the *N–*N, *N–*NH, *NH–*NH, and *NH–*NH2 adsorbed on Fe-C@C3N are plotted, respectively. From Fig. 9 , the synergistic effect of bonding and antibonding can promote the Fe-C@C3N to provide more electrons to the intermediates in order to further activate and elongate the N–N bond. As another typical descriptor, the integrated COHP (ICOHP) value is used to quantitatively evaluate the binding strength. And the more negative the ICOHP value indicates the higher the bonding degree. The ICOHP values of the N–N bond for *N–*N, *N–*NH, *NH–*NH, and *NH–*NH2 adsorbed on Fe-C@C3N are −20.30, −15.46, −11.99, and −10.51 eV, respectively. The corresponding d N–N are 1.17, 1.26, 1.38, and 1.43 Å (Fig. 5). It can be shown that with the process of hydrogenation, N–N bond is gradually activated, and the bond energy and bond length also monotonically decrease and increase, eventually leading to the destruction of N–N bond. Catalyst stability is also a key factor ensuring the smooth progress of catalytic reactions. Therefore, the influence of the Fe atom doped on the C3N surface on stability was analyzed. The projected density of states (PDOS) of the d orbitals of the Fe atom and p orbitals of the C and N atoms were plotted (Fig. 10 (a)). The results show that the Fe-3d, C-2p, and N-2p orbitals are obviously coupled below the Fermi level. This indicates the formation of stable bonds between Fe and the surrounding coordination atoms, suggesting the high chemical stability of Fe-C@C3N during the reaction. Finally, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation of the Fe-C@C3N catalyst was performed to determine its thermodynamic stability. From Fig. 10(b), it can be observed that the Fe-C@C3N structure is slightly deformed but retains its structural integrity after relaxation at 500 K for 10 ps, indicating that strong chemical bonds are formed between the Fe atom and C3N surface. Meanwhile, the energy of the system was constant during the entire simulation period, further indicating the good stability of the Fe-C@C3N system. 4 Conclusions In this study, the electronic structure of a two-dimensional C3N support was changed by TM atom doping, and TM-C2N and TM-C3 catalysts were designed as active sites for the electrocatalytic NRR. The best catalyst, Fe-C@C3N, was identified using DFT calculations of the energetics of N2 adsorption and activation, N2H formation, and HER inhibition, thus providing a theoretical basis for the preparation of new catalysts. Subsequently, the entire NRR catalytic process on the Fe-C@C3N surface was simulated. The results showed that the lowest limiting potential of –0.49 V was obtained through the enzymatic mechanism. The reason for the high catalytic activity of Fe-C@C3N was further clarified by analyzing the electronic characteristics. In particular, the large amount of charge transfer between the intermediates and Fe-C@C3N, as well as the strong hybridization between Fe-3d and C-2p and N-2p orbitals, enhanced the stability of the catalyst and ensured the smooth progress of the NRR. Therefore, the low limiting potential, good inhibition of HER, and high catalyst stability indicate that Fe-C@C3N is an NRR catalyst with high activity, selectivity, and stability. These findings provide suggestions for the development of catalysts for the sustainable production of NH3. coredata.dc:description: NH3 is the main product of nitrogen reduction and is not only an indispensable fertilizer component but also a promising clean energy carrier. The electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) can reduce N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions and is one of the most promising technologies to replace the traditional Haber–Bosch process. The careful choice and design of electrocatalysts are both key to achieving an efficient electrocatalytic reaction. In this study, using density functional theory calculations, the catalytic performance of a series of 3d transition metal (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co) single-atom catalysts supported on C3N (TM@C3N) was systematically investigated. The best NRR performance was achieved for the Fe-C@C3N catalyst, and the reaction follows the enzymatic mechanism. Crucially, at a limiting potential of –0.49 V, the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction was effectively inhibited. Furthermore, the electronic properties of the reaction intermediates and Fe-C@C3N were analyzed to reveal the reasons for its high activity. The results of this study will help us understand the catalytic performance of TM-atom-doped C3N and aid the design of more active C3N-based NRR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Computational screening of transition metal atom doped C3N as electrocatalysts for nitrogen fixation
